Topic.Title: a failure of the markets

Message.Msg: It's different than the other bubbles, for sure. For the last 4 years the scam-funds have learned how to keep bubbles in individual stocks going just as long as they please (and there are many like Amazon) while keeping the stock market afloat. It helps to have an inflationary monetary policy.

Topic.Title: a failure of the markets

Message.Msg: "a failure of the markets" I don't see any failure in the markets. If you want to short AMZN, you can. If you want to go long AMZN, you can. If you want to bet that AMZN will remain unchanged, you can. Anybody can make all sorts of bets imaginable any time (as long as they're legal) on AMZN. The markets have been functioning perfectly as far as I'm concerned. What are you people complaining about?

Message.Title: BBY online sales impact on AMZN
Message.Msg: Okay, I don't get how BBY improving on-line sales by only 4%-6% in markets where amnz collects taxes is a bad sign for amzn. I'm probably missing something here... Let's look at a simplified example (illustrative only): Let's say there are only two on-line competitors: amzn and bby Let's say that last year total sales = $100 and this year it went up 14% (see comscore) to $114. Let's say that sales were evenly split between amzn and bby last year. amzn sales = $50 and bby = $50 Well, if bby increased its sales by only 5% yoy, their on-line sales for this year = 1.05*$50 = $52.5. AMZN would have increased its sales to $61.5 or 23%. I guess the point I'm trying to make is that if bby doesn't increase its on-line sales by at least 14%, another company (amzn?) is increasing its market share.

Topic.Title: a failure of the markets

Message.Msg: Amazon's financial disclosures are equally as opaque as those guys. An analyst needs to ask point blank about comp sales for Amazon, 3P, FBA in states newly collecting tax versus those that don't. Amazon has those numbers and there is no "strategic" reason to refuse disclosure.

Topic.Title: BBY online sales impact on AMZN

Message.Msg: Absolute dollar amount is not what at stake, but rather the strategic picture and pipe-dream expectations of AMZN ability to grow revenues is what is exciting. BBY showed they can compete directly with AMZN on online-sales. Increased competition simply means less growth for AMZN. More importantly, it means AMZN will not be able to get to an "nutopia" where it simply could, ahem, "reduce it costs", "increase prices for everyone", and do whatever to rake in the pie-in-the-sky revenues and profits that would justify its current valuation; The number one concern of a consumer is to get a good enough deal. A good deal means first of foremost a good enough price, convenience, and the peace of mind that one is able to ask someone a question or quickly swap out a product. Up until now, due to the sales tax advantage, which is ending, AMZN could offer a price that overwhelmed the other factors. That's no longer the case, and that's why BBY online sales growth is a very critical validation point. AMZN is becoming a short in the style of NFLX -- maybe even much better, and much more devastating. NFLX, at least, had and still has somewhat of a niche, AMZN got dozen of very well-heeled and influential competitors along with thousands of smaller ones.

Topic.Title: a failure of the markets

Message.Msg: I think MS a week ago issued an upgrade in order to bump the stock above its triple top peak of about 260. Please go back an take a look at the chart. Then they eassigned AMZN to a different anaylst at MS. That guy issued a "buy". I guess the upgrade to outperform was not quite good enough for the boss or Bezos told the boss at MS to improve the recommendation level. That allowed them to hold on longer. The very day they did that, I believe strongly would have been the day when AMZN peaked and right now would have been trading undrer 240; maybe much lower. The technicals were precarious. That very day, the general market was down a lot. The next few days a few others, not to be outdone, jumped on the bandwagon with their upgrades of AMZN. It is really childish. These guys should be ashamed to be seen in public after being such fools. I would tell the CEO of MS right to his face what I think. Come on CEO, meet me for lunch. Are you afraid to talk common sense? I think you are. It is unethical at the very least when MS knows very well that their made up reasons are BS. They are in the bully pulpit, so they get to do that. The music will stop at some point, but not untll they let it or external events break the trend and even they have to capitulate. If you want to be on the winning side, you have to be one of them. So, decide how you want to live and decide whether it has been worth it the day you are on your death bed.

Message.Title: AMZN Momentum Play
Message.Msg: We've talked much about AMZN deteriorating strategic position. Let's talk momentum. Is AMZN the best current momentum play? If 300 is the target, we can expect around ~15% ROI going forward at this point. For a measly 15%, a long player takes the risk of a 50, 100, maybe even 150 pts hair cut. That'means, 20% - 50% downside risk. Are there really no other plays that provides a better risk/reward picture for a ~15% gain? Even GOOG would be a better play at this point. AAPL is another great candidate for a long play. QCOM raised earnings/revenues estimates. INTC has popped recently. CRM, CMG, NFLX, LNKD, FB seem to have some good momentum for at least 15% with seemingly less risk than AMZN.

Topic.Title: Forget about earnings, new paradigm is revenue growth - AMZN and FB will set new records

Message.Msg: Hence, the current play on AMZN is stay on the sideline, lock in long profits, or go short. Staying long, well, for what? If you don't know when it turns, you won't know when it turns, and if you have not locked in long profits, you have not gained anything ;) New longs? Got to be nuts...

Topic.Title: AMZN Momentum Play

Message.Msg: That's an interesting question. If you ran some institutional $$$, where would you put that $$$. Certainly not AMZN because of the small upside. Maybe FB... don't they have a "big" announcement coming out next week? Down-side is huge here. If they miss rev and eps on the q4 2012 report, they are likely going to go into a sustained downtrend. Question, how would you feel if you ran institutional $$$ and had a big investment in amzn? What would you do if you wanted out? Write a bunch of calls? Sell big chunks of stock and risk causing a panic among the other larger holders? Also, who would you sell to? volume has been lite.

Message.Title: Lock In Your Profits and Enjoy ;)
Message.Msg: Folks, lock in your long profits, buy a car, buy a house, go on a nice vacation, buy a boat, whatever. Until you have locked in your profits and enjoyed them (beside seeing numbers going up on a computer screen), you have really worked and worked and worked, but nothing to show for it ;) Enjoy your profits, your hard work because they could all be gone in an instant.

Topic.Title: AMZN

Message.Msg: If amzn reports 15 cent profit, then theoir 12 month trailing p/e would be N/A as in no profits. They need to earn 31 cents just to be break -even for the trailing 12 months. If they earn 61 cents a share, then their trailing p/e would be a mere 893. This company needs to earn $5/sh each quarter for a full year to justify their current share price. This will most likely NEVER happen despite all the pumped up literature from short sighted analysts and journalists out there. Keep up the good pump!

Message.Title: AMZN Holiday Quarter is a Mess?
Message.Msg: I start to see folks "pumping" AMZN clouds to counteract margin deterioration. However, “Look, we are happy to compete,” said Singh at the CloudBeat conference in Redwood Shores, Calif. “We believe our storage is actually better. We’re seeing some of the largest Amazon customers actually test and migrate over to our infrastructure because it is unique what we do.” In response to GOOG pricing, AMZN had had to lower its own pricing. Who got deeper pockets? GOOG or AMZN?

Topic.Title: AMZN Holiday Quarter is a Mess?

Message.Msg: From the same article... "Amazon, which held its own cloud conference this week, announced on Wednesday that it is lowering its cloud services pricing by 20 percent. This came only two days after Google announced that it lowered its cloud storage pricing by 25 percent. Google responded to Amazon’s price drop by taking an extra 10 percent off today." Oops...

Topic.Title: AMZN Holiday Quarter is a Mess?

Message.Msg: For the "only-revenue-matters" crowd, lower pricing also means lower revenues...oops again...;)

Topic.Title: I bought 99% of my XMAS gifts on AMAZON this year

Message.Msg: Of course if everyone else did the same, YOY online growth would have to, by definition, be more than 100%. Sadly, it was 14% as measured by $ sales (although likely higher in unit volume for those that understand the economics....). Pumper 101, you are supposed to pump with statements that could make sense.

Topic.Title: AMZN Holiday Quarter is a Mess?

Message.Msg: Actually, AMZN cut 25% to respond to GOOG's 20% and then GOOG raised the stakes another 10%. The thing is, Google's cloud customer base is much less material to its current or future earnings. AMZN just cut top line in one of its "cash flow" segments.
